channel.title: iDigital
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from iDigital, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: OpenMind raises $20M to connect intelligent machines
item.description: OpenMind has developed the OM1 operating system and FABRIC communications protocol to be robot-agnostic and scalable. The post OpenMind raises $20M to...

item.title: Here’s how to know if the S&P 500 is in the midst of a boom or a bubble
item.description: If you want to know where U.S. stocks are headed, look to the Fed, advises Societe Generale.

item.title: Tyson’s chicken business is growing, while beef is losing money even as prices jump
item.description: Tyson’s stock rises as earnings beat expectations, as strength in the chicken business offset weakness in beef.

item.title: Gold prices are soaring again. Here’s why a new record could be right around the corner.
item.description: U.S. growth, tariff-related inflation worries and a weaker dollar will drive gold to a new record, possibly within three months, says Citi.

item.title: Figma’s IPO success could push Canva and these other software companies to go public
item.description: D.A. Davidson sees Canva and Databricks as large software companies that could look to take advantage of a hot IPO market and speed up plans to go pub...

item.title: AMD’s stock has more than doubled off its lows. Does that bring earnings risk?
item.description: AMD’s stock rally looks overdone to analysts at Jefferies, who are expecting some pullback after the company reports earnings on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: The Download: fixing ‘evil’ AI, and the White House’s war on science
item.description: This is today’s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. Forcing LLMs...

item.title: Why tomorrow’s best devs won’t just code — they’ll curate, coordinate and command AI
item.description: AI coding requires a serious structural change. Where does that leave entry-level developers and the software industry as a whole?

item.title: Why the AI era is forcing a redesign of the entire compute backbone
item.description: GUEST: The past few decades have seen almost unimaginable advances in compute performance and efficiency, enabled by Moore’s Law and underpinned by sc...

item.title: Drone swarms: How they actually work and what industries should care
item.description: Drone swarms are distinguished by their decentralized behavior, which offers agility and cost savings for a range of applications. The post Drone swar...

item.title: Nextracker invests in field robotics and AI for solar power plants
item.description: Nextracker has acquired companies to deliver integrated technologies for utility-scale solar power and distributed generation projects. The post Nextr...

item.title: Reindustrialization won’t work without robotics
item.description: Learn why production robotics are essential for scaling automation, improving throughput, and closing the gap between reshoring ambitions and factory ...

item.title: New vision model from Cohere runs on two GPUs, beats top-tier VLMs on visual tasks
item.description: Cohere's Command A Vision can read graphs and PDFs to make enterprise research richer and analyze the documents businesses actually rely on.

item.title: Why open-source AI became an American national priority
item.description: To reflect democratic principles, AI must be built in the open. If the U.S. wants to lead the AI race, it must lead the open-source AI race.

item.title: DiffuseDrive addresses data scarcity for robot and AI training
item.description: DiffuseDrive says its physical AI system can build photorealistic data based on existing domain knowledge to speed physical AI performance. The post D...

item.title: Google releases Olympiad medal-winning Gemini 2.5 ‘Deep Think’ AI publicly — but there’s a catch…
item.description: The Gemini 2.5 Deep Think released to users is not that same competition model, rather, a lower performing but apparently faster version.

item.description: A new study from Anthropic suggests that traits such as sycophancy or evilness are associated with specific patterns of activity in large language mod...
